author: @VeronikaBenson
text: I‚Äôve been struggling a lot with loving myself in the face of my features I feel are ‚Äúvisibly trans‚Äù. I really appreciate that she said that we should love ourselves because we‚Äôre trans not despite it. It‚Äôs very difficult, tbh, especially with all the dysphoria and internalized transphobia. Laverne has always embodied confidence in ways that I look up to. So glad to listen to this interview.

replies.author: @twistysunshine
replies.text: This is something I've been working on a long time bc I've been avoiding certain transition things bc like, I didn't feel i hated parts of my body enough, or i was afraid of how people would read my very nonbinary approach.... I started thinking though that if I am doing this for joy, for the love of myself and who I want to be, then... That's enough. Transness should be about love as much as it can be about pain sometimes. Laverne is right

author: @that__girl_from
text: My favorite channel ‚ù§Ô∏è thanks Olay this conversation is so inspirational. I'm a  big/tall black trans woman, and this video is what I needed, and it's  funny how I spend all my time arguing with these bigots in the comments I'm pulling up studies  to prove my existence to these people. You are so right, Laverne, we don't have to debate our existence.

replies.author: @ChristopherSadlowski
replies.text: I'm recovering from eye surgery so I'm not seeing too clearly right now. I missed the "trans" part and was like, "Why are people debating the existence of tall Black women? There's a bazillion of them walking this world." I missed a pretty important word in your comment. üòÇ OMG, I'm a little embarrassed. I've also never understood that whole "trans people don't exist" because my tolerance for something so stupid is basically zero. "Debating" trans existence is like debating gravity...YOU CAN FUCKING SEE THEM EXISTING! You can see trans people with your own eyes existing in this universe. Like, of all the stupid things people say this has to be one of the dumbest.

author: @Theballonist
text:
Okay, two things. 1) The analysis that this woman brings is next level. She is giving us galaxy brain moment after moment.

2) How is Laverne Cox 51 but she looks younger than me? I'm pretty sure she is going to increase the average lifespan of humanity by several years all on her own.

replies.author: @23phoenixash
replies.text: This is not a slight against Laverne Cox (I think she's amazing), but money and opportunities can help. I'm not saying that's what happened with her, but poverty takes a toll on people physically and a recent study came out claiming that stress was as bad for our health as smoking. I don't know if THAT is accurate, but I definitely know stress is bad. It leads to inflammation of the body's systems and causes our brain to release different amounts of chemicals. Apart from that, I think being in the public eye leads people to tend more to their physical health and appearance, especially if future work/roles might depend on it. She could also just be lucky. I agree she looks great. Jealous! Haha.

author: @MamaJayde
text:
I never knew she was from Alabama. I live in Montgomery and I‚Äôm overwhelmed right now. I don‚Äôt even know why yet, but I‚Äôm crying. What an insight. I‚Äôm so proud of Luverne‚Äôs growth and I don‚Äôt even have to know how deep the depths of transformations she‚Äôs undergone. Being here most definitely speaks to resilience and heart. She‚Äôs such a blessing. It‚Äôs so hard to love yourself and others here.
It‚Äôs so hard not to lose hope, but I won‚Äôt.

author: @Empathy_is_Logical
text: When we police other people's expression of their identity, not only do we hurt them, but we deprive ourselves and the rest of the world of being able to witness the beauty of their self-expression and their personal journies. I look forward to when more people like me feel the same raw joy of seeing others unlike them feel safe and loved and happy in their communities and in the wider world.

author: @cthulhu8329
text: This conversation is so good. Balancing mental health and embracing who you are and your transition with real-world safety concerns and the knowledge (based on this year) that the safeties we sometimes take for granted can be reversed so quickly. Theres a transition surgery that I‚Äôve been waffling back and forth on because I‚Äôll ‚Äúpass better‚Äù and it will help me be more safe in public spaces, but I‚Äôm hesitant because I don‚Äôt want my transition to be based purely on safety and being palatable to other people. Laverne is such a wonderful person it was a joy to get to hear her thoughts and feelings.

author: @23phoenixash
text:
This was an amazing interview. Just a few of the things that I thought were great:

1) The part about how conservatives are mostly talking about white trans women and there being a usefulness in making being trans a "white" thing as a tool for division

2) How one should lead with their talent rather than their desperation.

3) And how we can't selectively numb things - when we numb the bad things, we're also numbing the good things. 

I really appreciate this. Looking forward to more great interviews. I'm always excited to learn new things or think about something in a different way. I'm absolutely going to remember these things and take inspiration from them. Thanks!

author: @usdeptoftwostatesolution
text: Always love hearing Laverne speak her mind. Shes been at this for over 30+ years and is clearly well-seasoned and versed in understanding the current Reality. Also, good point about working class (more so poc) folks can't afford the consequences of casual drug use. Not brought up enough how expensive those drugs really are on your life. They take away decades of potential earned income and growth.

author: @LexyconDevil
text: I appreciate this as someone who's known of Laverne Cox since the P. Diddy show. She was amazing in it and it's worth it to look at any clips of her in that or later when VH1 had a flash in the pan moment when they decided to let her host a make over show with two other trans women--TRANSformation or something like that. I wasn't out as a trans person but she was one of the figures that made me feel so much for trans women, because honestly she was funny, entertaining and fabulous--like, she was so charming in that Bush era of the 00s and even in the early 10s. I pretty much watched OITNB for her. She'll always be a welcome icon and personality for me, like she's always been way more than an actress though I hope she still lands some roles. I think she'd kill it in voice over work, personally!

author: @themfp3517
text: This just filled my heart to bursting and over SO many times! Such a deeply insightful conversation between beautifully reflective souls. I feel lucky to have the chance to see an exchange like this. Thank you forever for being who you are Olay.

author: @lowtech42
text:
7:26 Laverne name-dropping Savannah outta nowhere just GAGGED me!!! She gotta be doing something about Lady Chablis!!! Look her up if you don't know, she was truly iconic and mother and all those things, and walked so that the girls we admire these days could run. May she rest in peace üïä

EDIT: Now that I'm done let me just say that trans IS beautiful! For all the reasons Laverne mentioned sure, but also because of the light in her spirit that she embodies is truly incredible. She shares this characteristic with my other fave Alok Menon, and there's something to be said about it. When the world seeks to crush you from so many angles, you either die or you come away with the most profoundly enlightened experience with a deep sense of compassion and understanding. This has been the most beautiful interview!

author: @jessicametal7796
text:
Laverne Cox has been such an inspiration to me for such a long time. I came out at the end of 2012 and then to see this gorgeous, elegant woman be so unapologetically prominent and authentic has been something that has always been aspirational for me. Even when people were asking her horrendous and invasive questions in interviews, she would just curve their bs and refocus the conversation on what actually matters. 
And this convo proves that she's still the same woman as she was back then. <3

author: @argonianbum
text:
As two amazing individuals, seeing the chemistry between you and the great questions you got together for this discussion, I can't hope but feel optimistic for the future on many of these causes because, as much as it can seem hopeless sometimes, it's these alliances that form the dam needed against this bigotry.

As a sidenote, hearing Laverne talk about Lance and TYT etc made me so giddy. I knew you had amassed a great community online, but the absolute stardom threw me back!
